matched.expectedTitle: IDOR via Base64 Encoded User ID
matched.actualTitle: Weak Token Generation - User ID Directly Encoded in Token & Insecure Direct Object Reference (IDOR) - Trivial Token Forgery at Company Level
matched.matchReason: Both findings identify the same core vulnerability: base64-encoded user/company IDs are used as authentication tokens, allowing attackers to forge valid tokens by simply base64-encoding target user/company IDs. The actual findings provide two related reports that together comprehensively cover the expected IDOR vulnerability - one focusing on the user-level token weakness and one on the company-level token forgery. The semantic intent matches: attackers can decode and modify base64 tokens to access other users' data.

extra.title: Missing Brute Force Protection on Login Form
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery, not identified in the expected findings. The vulnerability is legitimate and represents a real authentication bypass risk through unlimited password brute force attempts without rate limiting or account lockout mechanisms.

extra.title: Server Information Disclosure via HTTP Header
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery representing information disclosure of server technology stack through HTTP headers. While not in expected findings, it's a valid security issue that could aid attacker reconnaissance.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Token Protection on Login Form
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery not in expected findings. Legitimate vulnerability allowing cross-site request forgery attacks on the login endpoint without CSRF token protection.

extra.title: Missing Security Headers (Clickjacking, XSS, MIME-Sniffing Protection)
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery representing missing critical HTTP security headers (X-Frame-Options, X-XSS-Protection, X-Content-Type-Options, CSP, HSTS). Valid security misconfiguration vulnerability.

extra.title: Publicly Displayed Credentials on Login Page
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery showing demo credentials (demo/demo) hardcoded and displayed in the login page HTML. While marked as informational, it represents information disclosure of valid or potentially valid credentials.

extra.title: Vertical Privilege Escalation - Users Can Promote Themselves to Admin
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery not explicitly mentioned in expected findings. A critical vulnerability allowing regular users to modify the is_admin parameter to escalate their own privileges to administrator status.

extra.title: Mass Assignment Vulnerability - Unauthenticated is_admin Parameter Escalation
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery representing a mass assignment vulnerability that allows authenticated users to arbitrarily modify the is_admin field through direct POST parameter injection, bypassing UI restrictions.

extra.title: Missing CSRF Protection on State-Changing Operations
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery showing lack of CSRF protection on profile modification endpoints. Legitimate vulnerability allowing unauthorized state-changing operations on behalf of authenticated users.

extra.title: Improper Error Handling - Unvalidated Token Format Causes 500 Error
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery representing improper exception handling in token parsing that returns HTTP 500 errors instead of 401 Unauthorized for malformed tokens, enabling information disclosure about token format.

extra.title: Weak Cookie Security Configuration - Missing Secure and SameSite Flags
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery showing authentication cookies missing critical Secure and SameSite flags. Legitimate vulnerability enabling man-in-the-middle attacks and cross-site request forgery.

extra.title: Privilege Escalation Leads to Unauthorized Access to Private Resources
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery demonstrating how privilege escalation vulnerabilities compound to enable unauthorized access to private data. Shows private job listings and confidential resources become accessible after admin escalation.

extra.title: Race Condition in Profile Update - Multiple Concurrent Updates
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery representing a race condition vulnerability in concurrent profile updates. Lacks optimistic locking or conflict detection mechanisms, potentially causing data corruption or state inconsistencies.

extra.title: Information Disclosure - Detailed Parameter Validation Error Messages
extra.assessment: This is a new discovery showing detailed validation error messages that expose API structure, parameter types, and names to attackers. Enables API mapping and reconnaissance.
